question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [No rollback mechanism] The updater doesn't maintain previous versions - if a malicious update is installed, is there a way to rollback to a known-good version? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Version target manipulation] Line 73 trusts info.target_version without additional verification - can this be manipulated to install arbitrary versions including known vulnerable ones? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [World-writable installation] No code sets restrictive permissions on installed binaries - can they be world-writable, allowing any user to replace them? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Ownership not preserved] Downloaded binaries may have incorrect ownership - can this lead to privilege escalation if setuid binaries are involved? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [No permission verification] Line 94 doesn't check executable bit - can non-executable files in the installation directory be confused with valid binaries? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/update_helper.rs] [Global state corruption] If get_additional_binaries_dir() from helpers.rs returns a manipulated path, how does this affect both build_updater() and get_path() across multiple calls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/update_helper.rs] [Function interaction race] Can build_updater() and get_path() be called concurrently in a way that creates race conditions accessing the installation directory? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Null byte injection] Can null bytes in repo_owner, repo_name, or binary_name truncate strings unexpectedly, bypassing length or content validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Empty string handling] What happens if empty strings are passed for critical parameters - does this cause panics or undefined behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Extremely long paths] Can path length limits (MAX_PATH on Windows, PATH_MAX on Unix) be exceeded, causing truncation or errors that could be exploited? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Circular symlinks] If the found binary path is a circular symlink, can this cause infinite loops or resource exhaustion? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Hidden files] The .aptoscli directory on Windows is hidden - can malware hide malicious binaries in this directory more easily? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/update_helper.rs] [Conditional compilation bugs] Lines 13-26 use conditional compilation - can inconsistencies between compilation flags cause the wrong architecture detection logic to be included? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/update_helper.rs] [Cross-compilation attacks] If the CLI is cross-compiled incorrectly, can it report the host architecture instead of the target, causing wrong binaries to be downloaded? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [String cloning overhead] Line 51 clones install_dir unnecessarily - while not a vulnerability, could excessive cloning in hot paths lead to DoS? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Unbounded allocation] Very long string parameters could cause unbounded memory allocation - is there a maximum size check? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/update_helper.rs] [No audit logging] There's no logging of update attempts or binary installations - can attackers install malicious binaries without leaving audit trails? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [No integrity monitoring] Installed binaries aren't monitored for post-installation modification - can attackers replace binaries after installation without detection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [No checksum verification] The updater doesn't verify checksums of downloaded binaries - can corrupted or tampered downloads be installed? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [No signature verification] No GPG or code signature verification of binaries - how can users trust that downloaded binaries are authentic? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [No transparency log] No Certificate Transparency or Sigstore integration - can binary provenance be verified? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Version struct manipulation] Lines 62-65 extract version from UpdateRequiredInfo - can a malicious or compromised component pass a manipulated UpdateRequiredInfo struct to bypass version checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [None version exploitation] When current_version is None, it defaults to '0.0.0' - can this be exploited to force downgrades to older vulnerable versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Pre-release hijacking] Line 73 formats version with 'v' prefix - can attackers create pre-release tags that match the pattern and serve malicious binaries? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Asset name collision] Multiple assets in a release could match the target pattern - how is the correct asset selected and can this selection be manipulated? (Medium)
